captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

I know I&#39;ve been picking on Ubisoft a lot lately, 
but nobody forced them to have a logo that looks

like a great big dog turd seen from above. Nobody 
forced Yves Guillemot to come out and declare

Skull and Bones to be a quote, quadruple-A game. 
You see, while no one deserves to be bullied,

if you march into the school cafeteria, plop down 
at the table with all the rough lads and declare

&quot;I&#39;d wager none of you fellows know as much about 
Naruto as me,&quot; then at that point you&#39;re kind of

asking for it. Especially when it turns out you 
don&#39;t actually know that much about Naruto. Making

this game should&#39;ve been the easiest fucking job 
in the world, Ubisoft, &#39;cos you&#39;d already done it.

You already made the pirate game we wanted. It was 
called Assassin&#39;s Creed Black Flag. All we wanted

you to do was strip out the Assassin business, cut 
the weirdly self-reflective evil tech corporation

in the future bits and add multiplayer. Well, I 
didn&#39;t want that, but I&#39;m not gonna burn down a

house just &#39;cos everyone besides me is having fun 
in it; not without deniability, anyway. And yet,

after ten long years to improve on the idea, Skull 
and Bones has less gameplay, less story, less

sandbox and Les Miserables. So &quot;less&quot; dock our 
ship at the island of &quot;Less&quot; bos and get into it.

We open with our character shipwrecked after a 
sea battle and some lady pirate apparently with

massive self esteem issues picks up our flystruck 
carcass and immediately pledges loyalty to us as

her new captain, &#39;cos she can see in our eyes 
that we&#39;ve got the spark of greatness, although

she might be confusing it for seagull plop. After 
a brief period of sailing a raft around getting

bullied by sharks we reach the central pirate 
island hub, where the king of the pirates gives

us a ship and some pirating jobs because he&#39;s got 
a good feeling about the look in our eye. Man,

what is it with our eyes? Who are we, the Demon 
Headmaster? Yes, I do get off on making references

most people won&#39;t get. I&#39;d already had the 
first major disappointment by this point.

Here&#39;s a list of things you can do with your ship 
in Black Flag: sail it, run around the deck, have

cool swordfights on it, climb the rigging, dive 
into the sea while your crew take the piss, etc.

Here&#39;s a list of things you can do with your ship 
in Skull and Bones: sail it, and don&#39;t sail it.

When you dock at an outpost your character just 
clicks their heels together and teleports to the

shore, and considering all you can do is jog from 
one vendor to another and can&#39;t even jump on top

of their desk and pretend defecate on their cash 
register, it might as well have been a fucking

menu screen. Maybe this is my fault for expecting 
too much; I&#39;m sure working multiplayer into the

established formula would&#39;ve added a lot of hidden 
complications, even letting us dive into the sea

would add legions of extra steps if it&#39;s other 
players who have to be the ones taking the piss.

I guess on that note one thing you can do on land 
is admire the custom avatars of other players,

but I swear every single other fucking 
player in this game was wearing the same

outfit - tricorne hat, eyepatch, overcoat. The 
moment I realised that I ran to the cosmetics

shop and traded my own tricorne hat, eyepatch 
and overcoat for a colourful stripey shirt,

shorts and a silly red hat and spent the 
rest of the game running around looking

like Ness from Earthbound. So that&#39;s the first 
paragraph of Skull and Bones&#39; suicide note:

the core gameplay is just ships. Ship movement and 
ship combat. If you want epic swordfights while

drenched in pitiless spray you&#39;re going to have 
to go back to taking showers with your brothers.

Ship movement consists of pointing to where you 
want to go and waiting, waiting a little bit less

if you have stamina and more when you&#39;ve run out. 
Hold up, question from the floor, Skull and Bones:

why does my ship have a sprint meter, and why is 
it restored with food items? What, are we climbing

down to the figurehead and shoving pancakes in its 
mouth? Gosh if only sailing ships had some bespoke

movement system that one could craft unique 
traversal gameplay around. &quot;Wind,&quot; you say? Nah,

I don&#39;t know what the wind&#39;s doing in this game, 
I think it&#39;s got ADHD. It keeps randomly changing

direction every thirty seconds like a long-term 
Ubisoft project. As for what you do once you get

to places, of course we&#39;re not getting out 
of here without doing some fucking crafting,

so we park next to the coast and gather bits of 
wood and ore with a sort of logical opposite of

a fishing minigame so that we can craft the 
better cannons that make us tough enough to

go to the next area with the slightly different 
bits of wood you need to craft the next kind of

cannon - it&#39;s annoying having to keep sailing 
right up to the coast. More often than not I

crash into it &#39;cos we can&#39;t just stop when we 
say stop. Which I&#39;d put down to being a sailing

ship but the same thing happens when you&#39;re 
on foot. Our dude has to awkwardly shuffle

forward a few steps like he&#39;s trying to find 
purchase on a floor covered in executive cum.

But resource gathering is made even more 
annoying by the inventory management,

the contextual prompts seem convinced we want to 
pick up every sweet wrapper and bit of floating

twig before the actually important stuff, and 
inventory is limited by both weight and item

slots for some reason. Our cargo can be a fraction 
of our ship&#39;s maximum weight but if it consists of

fifty different pieces of paper, whoops, no 
zinc ingots for you. Eventually I determined

it wasn&#39;t really worth resource gathering from 
coasts when it&#39;s a lot more fun and on brand

to pirate them from outposts and merchant ships. 
Yeah, it pisses off their faction but the factions

forget all about you after about ten seconds, 
maybe they have trouble telling the player

characters apart as well. And it&#39;s the combat 
where things finally get interesting. Again,

less interesting than it was in Black Flag, you 
can board enemy ships that you&#39;ve weakened but

then the game remembers it doesn&#39;t have 
hand to hand combat so it just goes &quot;Uh,

yeah, you won. It sank somehow. Move on. No 
need to dwell.&quot; But it&#39;s still got something.

The game came alive for me when I was doing a rum 
running side mission. Fast travel was disabled and

I had to make a gruelling journey across stormy 
open seas, harassed by privateers the whole way.

It was thrilling as I desperately tried to line 
up my cannons with the enemy as the sea rolled

and thrashed like an insomniac&#39;s honeymoon 
bedspread. But I finally arrived at port,

battered but exhilarated, to receive my just 
reward: twenty five premium coins. To put

towards eventually buying a two hundred coin hat 
exactly the same as the standard hats but a more

prestigious colour. Meanwhile the actual story 
missions are usually &quot;go to place for bog standard

ship fight. The big baddie we&#39;ve been building up 
for the last six missions is on the other ship,

you see. All very aggressively being not visible 
and not saying anything, ooh, don&#39;t you just hate

the smug bastard.&quot; In summary, if you&#39;re 
into online piracy - in a thematic sense,

I should say - just play Sea Of fuckin&#39; Thieves. 
That&#39;s what makes this even stupider. Ubisoft

had not only already made the game, they had a 
rival showing them exactly how to do it. They

had a white stick and a guide dog AND a fucking 
head-mounted sonar device and they still walked

straight off the fucking gangplank. Certainly 
is quadruple-A: Absolute Aggravated Anus Acne.

Sponsor time! My kids have had trouble 
sleeping, so I&#39;ve been looking for some

good educational family viewing on the benefits 
of a proper bedtime routine. I heard of a very

wholesome-sounding film called The Boy In The 
Striped Pyjamas which seemed ideal. Sadly it

was only available on Netflix UK, and I&#39;m in 
the US, but thanks to this week&#39;s sponsor,

NordVPN, I could watch it anyway. After a 
simple signup process all it took was one

click to divert my connection through a server 
in the UK and trick those stupid limey bastards

into thinking I was one of them. So my kids 
got their movie, and while I&#39;d prefer not to

go into the rest of the evening&#39;s events, on 
a related note, NordVPN&#39;s location services

were also great for finding the best prices
